P.title: Will a practical nuclear fusion reactor first be developed in China?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
For these purposes we define "practical" as an operational high-temperature nuclear fusion reactor that can (a) produce a demonstrated positive energy balance exceeding 100 megawatts for more than one week, and (b) have a sustainable plan for long-term operations (e.g. no critical hard-to-replace components that would be radiation-damaged to inoperability in a matter of days or weeks, etc.) These are chosen to roughly match this question.
This question will resolve as Yes if the first such reactor is built in China, and will resolve as No if the first such reactor is built anywhere else.
If no such reactor is built before January 1, 2050, this question will resolve as Ambiguous

para_P.title: Will China be the first country to develop a functional nuclear fusion reactor?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
A "functional" reactor is defined as one that is operational and capable of maintaining a high-temperature nuclear fusion process that produces a net energy output of over 100 megawatts continuously for at least one week, and has a viable plan for sustained operation without critical components failing due to radiation within a short period. This question will resolve as Yes if China constructs the first reactor meeting these criteria, and No if another country does so first. If no such reactor is developed by January 1, 2050, the resolution will be Ambiguous.

metadata.background_info: With an enormous amount of energy created per unit mass of fuel, cheap and abundance (e.g. deuterium) fuel, and relatively benign waste products, practical energy generation from nuclear fusion would be transformative for the world. A number of questions relate to efforts in the US and Europe, but there is another major player in the field: China. As discussed in this story, China is pouring significant resources into practical nuclear fusion.

P.title: If chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
Zermelo's theorem says that only one of three possibilities is possible in a 2-player solved game; First player (white) wins, second player (black) wins, or there is a forced draw.
In the game of chess, these outcomes correspond to:
White wins
Black wins
Forced draw
If chess is solved before 2080, must perfect play result in white winning?
For the purpose of this question, chess is considered to be solved if
it is proved that white will win, lose or draw from the initial position, given perfect play on both sides
it is shown that there exists a unique result of perfect play from the initial position, which is either: white wins, black wins, or forced draw
Resolution is by publication of peer-reviewed article that is not shown to be mistaken for at least 3 years post-publication.
For the purpose of this question, the 50-move rule does not force a draw. Games that don't end, are considered drawn, for the purpose of this question
This question resolves ambiguously if the question does not resolve before Jan 1st, 2080.

para_P.title: Should chess be solved by 2080, is it necessary that optimal play leads to a victory for white?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
According to Zermelo's theorem, a two-player game that is solved can only end in one of three ways: victory for the first player (white), victory for the second player (black), or a forced draw. In chess, these outcomes are:
- White wins
- Black wins
- Forced draw
Should chess be solved before the year 2080, is it imperative that perfect play by both sides results in a win for white?
Chess is deemed solved if:
- It is definitively proven that white will either win, lose, or draw from the starting position with perfect play by both players.
- It is established that there is a definitive outcome of perfect play from the starting position, which could be a win for white, a win for black, or a forced draw.
Resolution will be based on the publication of a peer-reviewed article that remains unchallenged for at least three years post-publication.
The 50-move rule does not apply in this scenario. Games that do not conclude are considered draws for this question.
This question will resolve ambiguously if it is not answered by January 1st, 2080.

P.title: Will there be at least 2˚C of global warming by 2100?
P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This question will resolve positively if, by January 1, 2100, there has been a period of at least 5 consecutive years in which the average global temperature in each year was at least 2.0 ˚C greater than the average global temperature in 1880.
(Note that 1880 isn't exactly pre-industrial, but earlier data is highly unreliable, and there should really not have been much warming by then.)
Data for resolution shall come from NASA, if possible. Note that the data in the link is normalised relative to the 1951-1980 baseline, on which 1880 stands at -0.2. Therefore, the critical value to look for with this specific NASA dataset will be 1.8 ˚C. It is likely, though, that the link will no longer be active in a few decades, so a different dataset may have to be used anyway.
The last possible set of 5 years to satisfy the requirement would be 2095-2099, so the last possible resolution date would be around mid-2100, in order to make sure that there are no uncertainties regarding the 2099 climate data

para_P.title: By the year 2100, will the Earth have experienced a minimum of 2 degrees Celsius increase in average global temperature?
para_P.body:
Resolution Criteria
This forecast will be considered accurate if, by January 1, 2100, there has been at least a five-year span where the annual average global temperature was at least 2.0 degrees Celsius higher than it was in 1880.
It is noted that 1880 is not precisely pre-industrial, but it is used due to the unreliability of earlier data, and minimal warming is expected from that time.
NASA will be the primary source for temperature data, if available. The data should be compared to the 1951-1980 average, with 1880 marked at -0.2 degrees Celsius on this scale, making 1.8 degrees Celsius the threshold for this dataset. However, the dataset link may become inactive over time, necessitating the use of alternative data sources.
The final five-year period that could meet this criterion would be from 2095 to 2099, with a final resolution by mid-2100 to ensure no uncertainties remain regarding the data from 2099.

metadata.background_info: At the Paris climate accord, world leaders promised to keep the global temperature increase this century (relative to pre-industrial levels) "well below 2 ˚C" and if possible below 1.5 ˚C. Many experts are skeptical about this goal being feasible, stating that even if all Paris targets are met, global warming may reach levels up to 3 ˚C above pre-industrial levels. Furthermore, with the coming departure of the United States from the agreement, the meeting of global targets may be in jeopardy.
